26 AUGUST.part4: Now therefore send quickly, and tell David, saying, Lodge not this night in the plains of the wilderness, but speedily pass over; lest the king be swallowed up, and all the people that are with him.
26 AUGUST.part5:
In David's psalms, he often thanked God for delivering him from his enemies. For example, in Psalm 18, he used the word "deliver" seven times to acknowledge God's deliverance. Today's passage is another such occasion where David managed to escape from Absalom's army. As in an earlier incident when David escaped Saul's assassins through the help of his wife Michal [1 Samuel 19], here he receives help from those God sent.

As soon as Hushai left the meeting with Absalom and his generals, he hastened to report to David via the priests Zadok and Abiathar as instructed by David earlier [2 Samuel 15:35]. The two priests then sent a maidservant to relay this information to their sons Jonathan and Ahimaaz who were waiting by the spring at Enrogel outside Jerusalem. There was no time to waste as it was likely Hushai did not know which proposal Absalom had adopted, his or Ahithophel's. Even if Absalom had accepted his, there was still the danger he could change his mind. David must immediately cross the Jordan before he and his troops are "swallowed up" by Absalom's army.

As followers of our Lord Jesus Christ, we too can call upon the Lord in our hour of distress and know that our cry will come before Him, even into His ears [Psalm 18:6]. Rest assured that the King of glory and Lord of hosts [Psalm 24:10] is able to deliver in the manner that is best for us and for the glory of His own name.
26 AUGUST.part7: Some trust in chariots, and some in horses: but we will remember the name of the LORD our God. - Psalm 20:7

27 AUGUST.part4: And when Absalom's servants came to the woman to the house, they said, Where is Ahimaaz and Jonathan? And the woman said unto them, They be gone over the brook of water. And when they had sought and could not find them, they returned to Jerusalem.
27 AUGUST.part5:
Ayoung man, possibly one of Absalom's spies, saw Jonathan and Ahimaaz talking to the maidservant and hurried back to report to Absalom. Realising they had been spotted, the two messengers fled and coming to a certain house in Bahurim, hid in the well in the courtyard. The brave woman of this house covered the well with a cloth, pretending to be drying the corn laid out on top of it. Her bravery and presence of mind saved their lives because Absalom would surely have killed them all if he found out the truth.

This nail-biting episode is yet another example of how the Lord used an ordinary woman to fulfil His plan for the redemption of mankind. We are reminded how Rahab saved the two spies in Jericho [Joshua 2] and ultimately became grafted into the line of David's ancestors. We also think of Esther, who apart from her physical beauty, was just an ordinary Jewish girl. But God used her to rescue the Jews from annihilation by Satan during the time of the Medo-Persian Empire. Thus preserved the children of Israel to welcome their Messiah, who would be born to the family of Joseph some four and a half centuries later.

The lesson of these stories for ordinary people like us is that we must be ready to serve the Lord when the opportunity arises; "and who knoweth whether thou art come to the kingdom for such a time as this?" [Esther 4:14].
27 AUGUST.part7: When God calls you, He enables you and He sees you through. - Warren W. Wiersbe in On Being a Servant of God

28 AUGUST.part4: Then David arose, and all the people that were with him, and they passed over Jordan: by the morning light there lacked not one of them that was not gone over Jordan.
28 AUGUST.part5:
The reader may heave a sigh of relief when he reads in verse 22 the happy ending in yet another dramatic episode in the life of David. The villain's plan is thwarted, and our hero escapes. Exciting though the narrative has been, still we all know there will be a happy ending because of the spoiler in verse 14, "that the LORD might bring evil upon Absalom".

This is the case throughout the Bible, whether it was the fate of Joseph in the Egyptian prison, Daniel in the lions' den or Mordecai in the Persian court. We know how the story will end because its Author says, "I am God, and there is none like Me, declaring the end from the beginning, and from ancient times the things that are not yet done, saying, My counsel shall stand, and I will do all my pleasure" [Isaiah 46:9b-10]. No wonder, Elwood McQuaid, author of the book It is No Dream, said that the history of Israel is pre-written history. God has already recorded it for us in Scripture.

This knowledge should give us the confidence to face the trials of life because we know who holds tomorrow. Warren Wiersbe said in his book, On Being a Servant of God, "If God has called you to minister, no matter what that ministry may be, He hasn't made a mistake. He knows what He's doing, and the best thing you can do is gratefully submit to His will and trust Him to work."
28 AUGUST.part7: Many things about tomorrow, I don't seem to understand. But I know who holds tomorrow, and I know who holds my hand. - Ira Stanphill

29 AUGUST.part4: And when Ahithophel saw that his counsel was not followed, he saddled his ass, and arose, and gat him home to his house, to his city, and put his household in order, and hanged himself, and died, and was buried in the sepulchre of his father.
29 AUGUST.part5:
Seeing that Absalom had rejected his counsel and chosen instead to listen to David's friend, Ahithophel decided to end his own life. His treacherous scheme to eliminate the former king had failed. His dreams had crumbled, and his carefully laid plans had come to nought. Hence, while David travelled to Mahanaim, Ahithophel returned to his home, set his affairs in order, and hanged himself. What caused him to do such a tragic thing?

Firstly, he could not bear the shame of being slighted. His ambition of being the power behind the new king appeared to be on the way to fulfilment until this unexpected turn of events. Secondly, his hope of leading the attack and basking in its victory had evaporated, leaving him without the power he sought. Thirdly, he assessed that inexperienced Absalom would be defeated. Given the needed time to recoup, David's battle-hardened and deeply loyal fighters would decimate Absalom's forces, after which he would be executed as a traitor. Basically, like Judas Iscariot, he must have sensed that he had been used by Satan and realised it was futile to "kick against the pricks" [Acts 9:5].

Ahithophel's fate teaches a precious lesson for all who live for the world, seeking wealth and success. Soon we will discover that all is vanity; and when things do not go our way, then there is nothing left worth living for. Let us seek first the kingdom of God and His righteousness; let us wait on the Lord, and He will grant us the desires of our heart.
29 AUGUST.part7: For what shall it profit a man, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own soul? - Mark 8:36

30 AUGUST.part4: Then David came to Mahanaim. And Absalom passed over Jordan, he and all the men of Israel with him.
30 AUGUST.part5:
David took the advice of Ahimaaz and Jonathan [v. 22], and fled to Mahanaim, a city on the other side of Jordan. Mahanaim was a fortified city with walls and gates, a suitable place to take refuge in [2 Samuel 18:24]. Importantly, Mahanaim was where David would be able to gather reinforcements. Mahanaim was also where the angels of God had met with Jacob, and where Jacob declared upon seeing the host of God's angels, that "this is God's host" [Genesis 32:1-2].

As David passed over to Mahanaim, Absalom too crossed the Jordan with his forces and pitched in the land of Gilead. Having accepted Hushai's advice, Absalom was now ready with all the men of Israel to engage David. Absalom replaced Joab with Amasa as the commander of Israel's army, appointing another of David's nephews to take charge of taking David's life.

Absalom's rebellion is staggering. He was not content with having ravaged his father's concubines openly [2 Samuel 16:22] and chasing his father out of Jerusalem to the other side of Jordan. At this point it was likely that Absalom had been already anointed as king [2 Samuel 19:10]. Yet Absalom's hunger to secure the crown and kingdom would not be satiated until he had utterly eliminated his father.

Absalom's open revolt turned a nation against itself, pitting family member against family. He forsook his namesake (Absalom means "father of peace") and pursued rebellion instead. Are we pursuers of God and peace, or do we find ourselves like Absalom, pursuing rebellion and our own desires?
30 AUGUST.part7: We need not fret ourselves because of evil men. Ultimately the evil will have no reward, and they will come to an end. Read Proverbs 24:19-20.

31 AUGUST.part4: Brought beds, and basons, and earthen vessels, and wheat, and barley, and flour, and parched corn, and beans, and lentiles, and parched pulse, and honey, and butter, and sheep, and cheese of kine, for David, and for the people that were with him, to eat: for they said, The people is hungry, and weary, and thirsty, in the wilderness.
31 AUGUST.part5:
At Mahanaim, David was received by distinguished hosts of great wealth and royalty: Shobi from Rabbah of the Ammonites was almost certainly from the royal family of Ammon, once an avowed enemy of Israel; Machir from Lo-debar, was a farmer who had taken care of Jonathan's son Mephibosheth and had been faithful to the house of Saul; and Barzillai the Gileadite was a wealthy man. These men met David in his need with great sympathy and substantial gifts.

So not only did David find refuge in Mahanaim, he also found hope in unlikely allies. This was the first sign that not everyone in Israel had fallen away from him. David and his men were comforted and relieved of hunger and weariness by these people's kindness. These men remain honoured today by their legacy of loving God and succouring God's people in their difficult times.

David was bereft of position, home, family and nation, but found comfort in the all-providing God. All manner of provision was made to David in a timely way. In the wilderness they had suffered want and scarcity. Here, they received plenty from their hosts and were strengthened for the battle ahead. Our God is a refuge and strength, a very present help in trouble. Even though everything around us may seem to be falling apart, we need not fear if God is with us, for He knows our every need.
31 AUGUST.part7: Day by day, and with each passing moment, Strength I find to meet my trials here; Trusting in my Father's wise bestowment, I've no cause for worry or for fear. - Carolina V. Sandell-Berg

1 SEPTEMBER.part4: And David numbered the people that were with him, and set captains of thousands and captains of hundreds over them. And David sent forth a third part of the people under the hand of Joab, and a third part under the hand of Abishai the son of Zeruiah, Joab's brother, and a third part under the hand of Ittai the Gittite. And the king said unto the people, I will surely go forth with you myself also.
1 SEPTEMBER.part5:
The eighteenth chapter opens with the inevitability of battle between David and Absalom. As the time for battle approached, David was in full command of his troops. He numbered his troops. He divided and placed them under his three generals, Joab, Abishai, and Ittai.

By all measures, the father-son confrontation was a tragic event. It would be interesting to go into David's mind and know his thoughts as he prepared to face his son in battle. It must have been a great conflict for him having to struggle between his being a king who has to put down an insurrection and his role as a father who loves his son. Victory is a must for David. However, victory for David would mean that his son would have to face the consequences for his sedition and treason. This would be a story without a happy ending.

We can go further back in time to see the causes that led to this sad state of affairs in the royal household. There were several factors, but it began with his sin of adultery with Bathsheba, which was compounded by the sin of deceit and the murder of Uriah when David tried to hide the first sin. The cover up gave Joab a hold over David.

A second factor was David's failure as a father. He did not discipline his sons when they committed egregious sins. David did nothing when Amnon violated Tamar, and he also did nothing when Absalom killed Amnon to avenge Tamar's honour [2 Samuel 13]. David's failures to discipline his sons led to an erosion of the people's support for him, leading to the crisis at hand.
1 SEPTEMBER.part7: "Watch ye and pray, lest ye enter into temptation" [Mark 14:38a]. Keep close to the LORD to keep your faith active and vibrant.

2 SEPTEMBER.part4: And David numbered the people that were with him, and set captains of thousands and captains of hundreds over them.
2 SEPTEMBER.part5:
David had recovered from his initial flight from Jerusalem and found refuge in the fortified city of Mahanaim [2 Samuel 17:24]. To prepare for the counter offensive, he numbered and reviewed his troops. He then appointed captains of thousands and captains of hundreds, and arranged them in three companies headed respectively by Joab, Abishai his brother, and Ittai the Gittite, knowing well the worth of able leadership, order and discipline. The three-pronged attack was a common military manoeuvre of this period [Judges 7:16; 1 Samuel 13:17].

Absalom led his large army of inexperienced men under the command of Amasa, across the Jordan and encamped in the land of Gilead [2 Samuel 17:24-26] to battle his father. David boldly assumed leadership to go with his men who were risking their lives for his cause, but was persuaded to remain at Mahanaim with the reserves both for his protection and to defend the city. The men said, "Thou art worth ten thousand of us" [v. 3], even if half of them died, the rest would carry on. But if David was killed, the cause was lost. So David acquiesced to their request. "What seemeth you best I will do" [v. 4].

"Whether the people's prudence had an eye to it or no, God's providence wisely ordered it, that David should not be in the field of battle; for then his tenderness would certainly have interposed to save the life of Absalom, whom God had determined to destroy." (Matthew Henry)
2 SEPTEMBER.part7: Onward Christian soldiers, Marching as to war. With the cross of Jesus, Going on before! Christ, the royal Master, Leads against the foe, Forward into battle, See His banner go. - Sabine Baring-Gould

3 SEPTEMBER.part4: And the king commanded Joab and Abishai and Ittai, saying, Deal gently for my sake with the young man, even with Absalom. And all the people heard when the king gave all the captains charge concerning Absalom.
3 SEPTEMBER.part5:
As the army marched before him for the final battle, the king specially commanded his three generals, "Deal gently for my sake with the young man, even with Absalom" and the people heard his instructions. However, David's order of leniency to spare Absalom's life would be brashly ignored by Joab and his men. Though Absalom premeditated Amnon's murder in revenge for his sister, abused David's concubines, conspired against God's anointed king, and set out to kill his father and appoint himself king, David still loved this wayward son very much. The love that David had for his son blinded him to the many defects and malicious designs of Absalom, a rebel against God's kingdom who deserved judgement and the death penalty.

Natural affection is a good thing [Romans 1:31] but not the only thing to consider; there are other priorities. What did our Lord Jesus teach about the relationship between natural affection and kingdom priorities? Read Matthew 10:34-39. Natural affection must be regulated to the honour of God.

Only God deserves our supreme devotion. There is no divided allegiance where He is concerned. "No man can serve two masters". No human love must be allowed to keep us from doing what He wants done. King David failed in this regard, behaving as a natural father would, rather than God's anointed. Whenever natural affection and partiality affect the judgement of God's leaders, it will lead to disagreement, discord and discouragement among His people. But notice that God's purpose and will are still accomplished - Absalom would be killed in God's providence, through Joab's wilful unrighteous act. Godly leaders must boldly pursue kingdom priorities in faith.
3 SEPTEMBER.part7: Love and duty are inseparable. Is my love strengthened by the exercise of spiritual discipline?

4 SEPTEMBER.part4: For the battle was there scattered over the face of all the country: and the wood devoured more people that day than the sword devoured.
4 SEPTEMBER.part5:
The battle (civil war) was fought in the forest of Ephraim. The bitter civil war was instigated by David's worthless and treacherous son Absalom. Civil war is always a terrible calamity but when the rebellion is raised by a son against his father, we have the most painful form of strife.

The battle was scattered, meaning it was a series of separate encounters covering the entire battle zone in which David's three divisions attacked and routed Absalom's men. Casualties among his troops numbered over 20,000 soldiers. Better-disciplined and better-led than the hastily mustered forces of Absalom, the soldiers of David broke the ranks of their enemies and sent them to seek shelter in the dense forest. The battleground was well suited to David's experienced and brave soldiers rather than the many inexperienced men of Absalom. "The wicked flee when no man pursueth: but the righteous are bold as a lion" [Proverbs 28:1].

The woods devoured more people than the sword. The verb "devoured" literally means "to eat or consume". Even the woods are dangerous when you are out of the will of God by being disobedient to His cause! God intervened on David's behalf. David's troops were able to use the rugged terrain and dense growth of the forest to their advantage. Perhaps wild beasts that infested the forest killed many distracted and displaced Israelites. Because of the rugged terrain, the pursuit through the thick forest resulted in more deaths than did the actual combat. David's men, though fewer in number, won the civil war. The God of Israel would not suffer His anointed to perish, nor the impious usurper to triumph over him.
4 SEPTEMBER.part7: Perhaps Amnon's murder, Absalom's rebellion and the civil war within David's kingdom could have been avoided if David had chosen to confront sin rather than dismiss it.

5 SEPTEMBER.part4: And Absalom met the servants of David. And Absalom rode upon a mule, and the mule went under the thick boughs of a great oak, and his head caught hold of the oak, and he was taken up between the heaven and the earth; and the mule that was under him went away.
5 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Despite Absalom's popularity and larger army, he still lost the battle against David. Having all worldly advantage was of no avail. Absalom could not overcome David with God on David's side. In today's reading we see that Absalom encountered David's servants in the aftermath of that disastrous battle and attempted to flee. However, as he was riding away on his mule, his head was caught on an oak branch and he was left hanging in mid-air. He was in a great predicament, rendered completely defenceless and hanging helplessly where he could be mocked by any passers-by. This would have been especially humiliating for Absalom who was greatly concerned with people's opinion of him.

Worse than that, we see that material advantages could not give Absalom victory over David. Although Absalom had plotted this rebellion deviously and won the hearts of the Israelites, in God's eyes Absalom was just another rebel. The Israelites might believe that Absalom was the rightful king, but the Bible is clear that the Lord hates a rebellious son [Proverbs 15:5,20; 30:17]. In acting to usurp David's throne and win the kingdom, Absalom was guilty of rebellion against his father.

Often, we come up with justifications and excuses for what we perceive to be our minor sins. However, let us remember that we are children of God and sin is rebellion. So let us not rebel against our heavenly Father.
5 SEPTEMBER.part7: Do I often make excuses for sins which I perceive to be minor?

6 SEPTEMBER.part4: Otherwise I should have wrought falsehood against mine own life: for there is no matter hid from the king, and thou thyself wouldest have set thyself against me.
6 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Joab was a powerful figure by David's side. He was also a dangerous man who would not hesitate to kill for his own gain [2 Samuel 3:27]. Today, we read that a man had witnessed Absalom's predicament and informed Joab, only to be rebuked for not slaying him. We will consider this nameless man's wisdom in choosing not to obey Joab's command to kill Absalom.

First, we see that he knew the will of David, the one with true authority. He reminded Joab that David had given orders for Absalom not to be harmed. He would not disobey the king's order, not even for a great reward. Second, we see that this man was wise in knowing that his actions would not be hidden forever. One's sin will find one out. Finally, we see that this man was astute in regarding Joab's character. He knew even though Joab promised him a reward for killing Absalom, Joab would also not actively come to his defence if he was found out.

When we are tempted by others to sin, let us too be reminded of these three things. First, remember that no matter what the authority of the person tempting us to sin is, we are subject to God who is the highest authority above all. Second, remember nothing can be hidden from God. Even if we hide our deeds from the world, there is no hiding from the omniscient God. Third, remember that no human being can protect us from the consequences of our sins.
6 SEPTEMBER.part7: Dabbling in sin is akin to gambling with your own life.

7 SEPTEMBER.part4: Then said Joab, I may not tarry thus with thee. And he took three darts in his hand, and thrust them through the heart of Absalom, while he was yet alive in the midst of the oak.
7 SEPTEMBER.part5:
From a human perspective, we can perhaps understand why Joab took matters into his own hands. We know that David was in two minds about this battle. On the one hand, his men were fighting for him to be reinstated to the throne. On the other, his son's life was at stake. As such, David, subject to human weakness and fatherly love, had given the command for his soldiers to be merciful to his son, which would have adversely impacted his soldiers' morale.

Despite his many faults, Joab was loyal to David. Here, we see his obedience was a subjective one. He was prepared to disobey David for what he believed to be for David's own good. It is possible Joab had good reason for killing Absalom. By doing so, Joab eliminated the possibility of future threats against David. But Joab put Absalom to death in a cruel and merciless manner. He stabbed him through the heart and then left his men to finish him off.

Let us be reminded that unlike Joab who was subordinate to a king who had his many moments of human weakness, we have a God who is never weak or wrong. He is perfect even in mercy and judgement. As such, we must not be selective in submitting to His commands. Often, it is easy to obey God when it is convenient to do so. However, it is more important for us to remain submissive during the times we do not fully understand God's will.
7 SEPTEMBER.part7: Consecrate me now to Thy service, Lord, By the pow'r of grace divine; Let my soul look up with a steadfast hope, And my will be lost in Thine. - Fanny J Crosby

8 SEPTEMBER.part4: And they took Absalom, and cast him into a great pit in the wood, and laid a very great heap of stones upon him: and all Israel fled every one to his tent.
8 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Now that the battle was done, they threw Absalom's corpse into a deep pit and covered it with stones in an act of scorn and contempt. Absalom's hanging and death, and his body's crude disposal give us a picture of God's hatred against rebellion. We may see that hanging on the tree parallels past hangings of Israel's accursed enemies [Joshua 8:29; 10:27]. We may also see that the disposal under stones is suggestive of the punishment God had ordained for rebellious children [Deuteronomy 21:21].

As we read this account of Absalom's death, we may feel a sense of justice served. We may believe that Absalom received his just deserts. A rebellious child is universally disliked in any society today. Let us consider the Old Testament punishment and death reserved for rebellious children. The truth is that, like Absalom, we are also guilty of the sin of rebellion against our heavenly Father. Just as we may have felt that justice was upheld in Absalom's death, we should not forget this is the same way justice will be upheld if we were subject to the Law.

Then let us consider how our Lord Jesus Christ's death on the cross and subsequent burial has put an end to that Law's requirement and satisfied its penalty. Our Lord Jesus died a painful, merciless death on our behalf. The wrath God poured out upon our Lord that day at Calvary was fury that we have incurred through our rebellion. Let us therefore be ever grateful to the Lord Jesus Christ our Saviour.
8 SEPTEMBER.part7: His robes for mine: God's justice is appeased. Jesus is crushed, and thus the Father's pleased. - Chris Anderson

9 SEPTEMBER.part4: Now Absalom in his lifetime had taken and reared up for himself a pillar, which is in the king's dale: for he said, I have no son to keep my name in remembrance: and he called the pillar after his own name: and it is called unto this day, Absalom's place.
9 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Verse 18 is a postscript of Absalom's life. It was his eulogy after his death at the hand of Joab, but it was not a very flattering one. Absalom was known for his looks. The Bible says that "from the sole of his foot even to the crown of his head there was no blemish in him" [2 Samuel 14:25]. He wanted to be known for his greatness. He also had grandiose ideas about himself.

Presumably, Absalom contrived a scheme to perpetuate his memory after he was allowed to return to Jerusalem. As he rose in popularity, we read that "in his lifetime had taken and reared up for himself a pillar ... and he called the pillar after his own name: and it is called unto this day, Absalom's place". The word "place" literally means "hand", speaking of his "accomplishments". But what great deeds had Absalom accomplished up to the day of his death? Consider what Absalom would be known for? His dastardly act of fratricide [2 Samuel 13:28-29] and an attempted regicide [2 Samuel 15:14].

See the vanity of Absalom in raising a pillar to his own name! Note also its futility. He had intended the monument to be a record of his greatness after his death because he had no son, but it became a memory of his shame. Absalom might have wanted the pillar to be his cenotaph, but he was ignominiously buried in an unmarked grave under a heap of stones.

Learn the lesson of Absalom's life and death - beware of the instruments of vainglory; beware of the allure of ill-gotten gains; beware of pride and self-glory.
9 SEPTEMBER.part7: "And seekest thou great things for thyself? seek them not" [Jeremiah 45:5a]. Seek, instead, the glory of God.

10 SEPTEMBER.part4: And Joab said unto him, Thou shalt not bear tidings this day, but thou shalt bear tidings another day: but this day thou shalt bear no tidings, because the king's son is dead.
10 SEPTEMBER.part5:
From the battlefield where we witnessed the tragic end of the wicked and proud Absalom, we now turn to three men, Joab, Ahimaaz and Cushi as the outcome of the battle is conveyed to David. Inevitably, the news of Absalom's death must be told to his father. Ahimaaz the son of Zadok offered to bring the news to David [v. 19].

Ahimaaz's loyalty to David was without question. At a time when the hearts of men were stolen by Absalom [2 Samuel 15:6], Ahimaaz remained loyal to the old king even when he was fleeing for his life [2 Samuel 15:27, 36].

Ahimaaz's enthusiasm, however, was curbed by Joab's astuteness. It could be that Joab was wise to know that the king would react unfavourably to the news of his son's death. Joab was keenly aware of David's love for Absalom. And the report of Absalom's defeat, far from being the news of victory, would bring much distress for David because winning the battle would mean his losing his son. It could also be possible that the bearer of bad news would bear the brunt of David's sorrow and fury.

On a more cynical note, Ahimaaz was prevented from carrying the news to David because Joab was afraid that he would be exposed for defying the king's explicit orders to spare his son [v. 5]. Perhaps, that is why Joab sent Cushi instead, who being a foreigner would have known nothing of David's original order.

Ahimaaz was enthusiastic about bearing the news of the death of a son because of his devotion to David. We too have similar tidings - the sacrificial death of the Son. Let us be just as prompt in our devotion to our Lord Jesus Christ and in the dissemination of His Gospel.
10 SEPTEMBER.part7: How beautiful are the feet of them that preach the Gospel of peace, and bring glad tidings of good things! - Romans 10:15b

11 SEPTEMBER.part4: But howsoever, said he, let me run. And he said unto him, Run. Then Ahimaaz ran by the way of the plain, and overran Cushi.
11 SEPTEMBER.part5:
In place of Ahimaaz, Joab dispatched Cushi, which is not a proper name; rather he was an Ethiopian in Joab's service. Despite the fact that Joab had already given the mission to Cushi, and his dumping cold water on Ahimaaz's enthusiasm - "Wherefore wilt thou run, my son, seeing that thou hast no tidings ready?" [v. 22b] - Ahimaaz was insistent.

"But howsoever, let me ... " [v. 22a]. Ahimaaz's persistence paid off in the end. "Run" was Joab's response as he acquiesced.

The battle was fought in "the wood of Ephraim" [v. 6b], which was a thick forested area east of the Jordan River. The Cushite took the road over the hills in a straight southerly direction toward Mahanaim. It was a shorter but a more difficult route.

Ahimaaz, on the other hand, "ran by the way of the plain", which was the name of the Jordan valley near Jericho. This route would mean that Ahimaaz first must head west across the Jordan River before heading south. The two routes would eventually converge a short distance from Mahanaim. The "way of the plain" was longer, but it was an easier route. So, Ahimaaz "overran Cushi".

On Ahimaaz's enthusiasm and persistence, Charles Spurgeon comments, "In reading this passage, it strikes me that if men vie with each other in common matters, and one outruns the other, I ought to be in solemn earnestness so to run that I may obtain. Lord, help me to gird up the loins of my mind, and may I press forward towards the mark for the prize of my high calling of God in Christ Jesus."
11 SEPTEMBER.part7: Father in heaven, help me to bear patiently under trials or rejections, to run with zeal the race set before me even amidst challenges and difficulties. In Jesus' name, Amen.

12 SEPTEMBER.part4: And the watchman said, Me thinketh the running of the foremost is like the running of Ahimaaz the son of Zadok. And the king said, He is a good man, and cometh with good tidings.
12 SEPTEMBER.part5:
This passage portrays a graphic description of the runners Cushi and Ahimaaz and their arrival at Mahanaim. King David had taken his place at the city gate while a watchman was stationed on the walls to look out for anyone coming with reports of the battle [v. 24].

The watchman saw the first man running alone. As he drew nearer, a second runner was sighted. David perceived both runners were bringing news [v. 26]. The watchman then made out the first runner to be the son of Zadok. Hearing his name, David concluded that Ahimaaz being sent must indeed mean good news. "He is a good man, and cometh with good tidings." Underlying David's words is his assumption a good man must bring good news.

What would be good news for David? It would be what he desired to hear; that the life of Absalom was spared. That, however, was not to be. David would soon learn that his rebellious son was dead.

What would be good news for a sinner? The Gospel, of course; that God loves us and sent His only begotten Son, our Lord Jesus Christ, into the world to save us from our sins and provide the way to everlasting life. But the Good News would also mean the "bad news" of the death of the rebellious heart. The Good News that gives hope also reveals that all men are sinners and unless they repent and place their faith in the Lord Jesus Christ as their Saviour, there awaits every sinner God's fearsome wrath and eternal judgement. May we be the faithful messengers running earnestly to deliver the truth that "he that believeth on the Son hath everlasting life: and he that believeth not the Son shall not see life; but the wrath of God abideth on him" [John 3:36].
12 SEPTEMBER.part7: Father in heaven, help me to be a faithful and courageous messenger of your Gospel which convicts sinners and saves them to the uttermost. In Jesus' name, Amen.

13 SEPTEMBER.part4: And Ahimaaz called, and said unto the king, All is well. And he fell down to the earth upon his face before the king, and said, Blessed be the LORD thy God, which hath delivered up the men that lifted up their hand against my lord the king.
13 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Ahimaaz yearned so much to bring David good news after the battle that he persuaded Joab to allow him to carry the news back [v. 22-23]. Was he out to "curry favour" with his king? "All is well" in Hebrew is "shalom" or "peace"; but we know that while the battle was won and David's kingship secured, David's heart was not going to be well.

Do we have friends like Ahimaaz in our life? Friends who tell us "all is well" and inadvertently give us the false assurance of worldly peace. We may have stable jobs, nice houses, good health and all seems well. But as we peer into the depths of our souls, are we as certain all is well. We know temptations assail us and sin besets us, unless we resort to our Lord Jesus Christ and cling to His cross.

Our Lord Jesus tells us there is a difference between worldly peace and Godly peace: "Peace I leave with you, My peace I give unto you: not as the world giveth, give I unto you" [John 14:27a]. The circumstances of our lives may be well, others may tell us we are well, but it is only after reflection and examination of ourselves that we can ascertain whether we are truly well.

Beloved, are we satisfied with being "well" according to the world's standards? Or do we desire to be "well" before our Lord and by His standards? Constant self-reflection and examination is the key.
13 SEPTEMBER.part7: Do we examine our actions and reflect on our thoughts regularly? Is there self-awareness of our sins?

14 SEPTEMBER.part4: And the king said, Is the young man Absalom safe? And Ahimaaz answered, When Joab sent the king's servant, and me thy servant, I saw a great tumult, but I knew not what it was.
14 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Ahimaaz was so eager to bring good news that he lied about Absalom's fate. He told David some truth but not the whole truth.

Have we been placed in similar situations where it would be too awkward, embarrassing or socially impolite to tell our loved ones the 'whole truth'? So we rationalise and prevaricate: "It's not my position to tell him, someone closer will tell him about his sin". In order to look good and avoid awkwardness, we choose the path of Ahimaaz. We omit the whole truth and tell a "white lie".

If we cherish our loved ones, the right thing would be to speak honestly but lovingly about the person's shortcomings, weaknesses or sin. A Christian brother was getting married to a non- believer and his friends did nothing to stop him. Years down the road after their divorce, he came to his friends and said: "You knew I was doing the wrong thing but you did nothing about it, how can I call you guys my friends?"

"A friend loveth at all times, and a brother is born for adversity" [Proverbs 17:17]. A real friend is one who experiences both joy and adversity with you. If we only want to experience the joy and leave the adversity to others, then we are not true friends. If we truly love the people we say we love, we will not spare their feelings to mention hard truths they need to hear.
14 SEPTEMBER.part7: Faithful are the wounds of a friend; but the kisses of an enemy are deceitful. - Proverbs 27:6

15 SEPTEMBER.part4: And the king said unto Cushi, Is the young man Absalom safe?
15 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Have you ever experienced moments in your life when your mind was too preoccupied with someone, something or some situation that you find yourself constantly distracted by it? Your heart tells you that you will not be at ease until you obtain or achieve it. This could be the case for those who are anxiously awaiting the results of a job interview/promotion, desiring a 'soul mate' or even an addiction to some worldly entertainment or thing the world has to offer.

David's preoccupation was with his beloved son Absalom, now dead. God's higher will was momentarily lost from David's sight. He expressed no thanks to the Lord for His great deliverance. He showed no concern for Joab and his men who had fought and were spent for him. David's mind was solely focused on his son to the exclusion of all else. Absalom had become David's idol. The Lord told Israel not to bring any idols into their homes for they will soon become as degraded as their idols [Deuteronomy 7:26]. We are enslaved by whatever we worship, and if our idols of wealth, worldly desires and entertainment occupy first place in our heart, we will be enslaved by them and soon find ourselves constantly wanting more and more.

We indulge in our idols and sinful pleasures to find contentment and satisfaction for the void in our hearts, but there is no fulfillment in these. The objects of the world are vanity. It is the Lord alone who can give us true contentment in our hearts.

Recognise the idols that control you and pray for strength to place God and His Word first.
15 SEPTEMBER.part7: What are the idols in your heart? Do they have a grip on your life? Surrender them to the Lord.

16 SEPTEMBER.part4: And the king was much moved, and went up to the chamber over the gate, and wept: and as he went, thus he said, O my son Absalom, my son, my son Absalom! would God I had died for thee, O Absalom, my son, my son!
16 SEPTEMBER.part5:
The author could simply have written "David mourned for his son". Instead he gave us a detailed description of David's grief. Considering this and Nathan's words in 2 Samuel 12:10a that "Now therefore the sword shall never depart from thine house", we can see that David's grief was compounded with guilt.

David's sin of adultery with Bathsheba and murder resulted in the consequence of Absalom's death which is why David lamented "would God I had died for thee". David knew he deserved death for his sins, yet he was alive, and his son lay dead. God's chastisement and discipline was more painful than death for him. However, despite the anguish and sorrow David felt through God's discipline, there was also much grace in store for him. As we will see in the days ahead, God loved David and chose his son (from Bathsheba), Solomon, to be the next king. Solomon would be the richest and wisest king in Israel's history.

In times of sorrow and grief, the person we need most to be with is our Lord. To Him we can pour out our anguish, and cast all our cares and troubles because He cares for us. While the hand of God may seem heavy for a season, remember that the yoke of our Lord Jesus Christ is light and we can lean on Him for strength.

No matter how dark the night may seem, joy comes in the morning when the dawn breaks. There is always grace to be found if we will just draw closer to the Giver of grace.
16 SEPTEMBER.part7: For His anger endureth but a moment; in His favour is life: weeping may endure for a night, but joy cometh in the morning. - Psalm 30:5

17 SEPTEMBER.part4: And the victory that day was turned into mourning unto all the people: for the people heard say that day how the king was grieved for his son.
17 SEPTEMBER.part5:
The passing of a loved one is never easy to bear, especially if the person is one's child. Absalom was David's son, and it is clear from today's passage (and 2 Samuel 18:5) David was a passionate man who loved his children, even one who had caused him so much harm as Absalom. David could not bring himself to say "I shall go to him" [2 Samuel 12:23] because he knew that in the final reckoning and in the resurrection to come, Absalom will not be found together with him and therefore he lamented, "O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!" [v. 4]. However, David failed to realise the effect his reaction would have on the morale of his soldiers and servants who had fought bravely and obtained victory for him against Absalom.

As a result of David's grief, the army's victory celebration soured, turning it into a day of mourning. The men tip-toed around stealthily like men who had lost the battle and were in shame. What an adverse effect David's anguish had on the mood of his army! David was stuck in an emotional rut and this cast a pall over an otherwise celebratory occasion. He had allowed his personal feelings to become a stumbling block and humiliation to those who had served him sacrificially.

Dear readers, in whatever circumstance we find ourselves, let us realise that God has allowed the events to come to pass and we can trust His sovereign will.
17 SEPTEMBER.part7: Do all things without murmurings and disputings: That ye may be blameless and harmless, the sons of God, without rebuke, in the midst of a crooked and perverse nation, among whom ye shine as lights in the world. - Philippians 2:14-15

18 SEPTEMBER.part4: But the king covered his face, and the king cried with a loud voice, O my son Absalom, O Absalom, my son, my son!
18 SEPTEMBER.part5:
While the army had won the battle against their foes and slained Absalom the architect of the rebellion, we see David, instead of rejoicing in the victory, lamenting grievously the death of his son. The root of the problem lies in self-pity. We see this when a child loses in a game, and he sulks and refuses to continue playing with his friends. We see this in adults when a worker misses out on a promotion, and rather than working harder for the next round, he mopes and bad-mouths his bosses and colleagues, and finally resigns from the job.

Self-pity is a destructive sin that leads a Christian to lose his effectiveness in his service to man and to God. He becomes negative and self-centred caring only for himself. He puts himself above others, even God. At its root, self-pity causes a Christian to assess his situation and himself outside the grace of God, even to the extent of blaming God for not giving him the outcome he desires.

So, how do we avoid self-pity and not let its root grow in our psyche? Firstly, we should not think of ourselves more highly than we ought to think [Romans 12:3]. Secondly, place God in the centre of our lives, by submitting to His sovereign will, being thankful and accepting that whatever God gives us is from a loving and gracious Father.
18 SEPTEMBER.part7: In every thing give thanks: for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus concerning you. - 1 Thessalonians 5:18

19 SEPTEMBER.part4: And Joab came into the house to the king, and said, Thou hast shamed this day the faces of all thy servants, which this day have saved thy life, and the lives of thy sons and of thy daughters, and the lives of thy wives, and the lives of thy concubines;
19 SEPTEMBER.part5:
David was caught in a dilemma. As a father, he loved his son. As a king, he must exercise justice. Here, David made a wrong judgement. His indulgent love for his son blinded him to Absalom's abominable treachery. So, we find David wallowing in self-pity [v. 4], spiralling downwards in a vicious cycle of negativity until Joab confronted David. Joab said, "Thou hast shamed this day the faces of all thy servants ... in that thou lovest thine enemies, and hatest thy friends ... for this day I perceive, that if Absalom had lived, and all we had died this day, then it had pleased thee well" [v. 5-6].

These words must have stabbed into David's heart, but Joab's words were true. If Absalom were successful in his insurrection, David would have lost his life, and there would have been a massacre of his sons and daughters, and the rest of the family who fled with him [v. 5]. The soldiers who stood with David in the rebellion would also be certainly put to the sword. It was this horrible prospect that moved Joab to give David a stern rebuke, bidding David to suppress his mere personal feelings.

David's depression was not the result of what he knew - Absalom's death and his own role in it. David's problem was in what he forgot - that God was still in control, that a great victory was won, that the insurrection was put down, that he had many loyal supporters, and that God was gracious and merciful to David in spite of his sin. So, instead of lamenting, "O Absalom, my son, my son!" [v. 4], David should have called, "O my God, my Lord."

The remedy to depression is not to focus on what we have lost, but to remember what we have gained in our Lord Jesus Christ.
19 SEPTEMBER.part7: Let us lay aside every weight, and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us, looking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith. - Hebrews 12:1b-2a

20 SEPTEMBER.part4: In that thou lovest thine enemies, and hatest thy friends. For thou hast declared this day, that thou regardest neither princes nor servants: for this day I perceive, that if Absalom had lived, and all we had died this day, then it had pleased thee well.
20 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Joab further rebuked David for his insensitivity. When David mourned for Absalom in such a manner, he showed that he loved his enemies and hated his friends. In his reality check, Joab chided David, it was as if he was declaring that had Absalom lived and everyone else died, he would have been pleased.

Let us learn from this incident that we should be sensitive to those around us. Most of all, Christians must be sensitive to God's prompting. God has given each of us at least a talent and ministry; it may be as a church leader or other roles in church ministry, or it could be a ministry elsewhere, such as taking care of our children's spiritual growth at home, or being a testimony at work or school. We are to magnify our Lord in these roles by our thoughts, words and deed. Being sensitive to others does not only mean attending to their physical needs. Even machines can do that nowadays. Sensitivity and concern should stem from empathy towards others, and by esteeming them higher than ourselves [Philippians 2:3-4]. Heed these words from the apostle Paul, and live it in our lives, so these qualities will manifest not just in our actions, but also our words and attitudes toward others.

Thank God for faithful friends, even one like Joab, whom God used to turn the mourning and sorrowing of King David, and raise him up again from the pit of self-pity.
20 SEPTEMBER.part7: Brethren, if any of you do err from the truth, and one convert him; Let him know, that he which converteth the sinner from the error of his way shall save a soul from death, and shall hide a multitude of sins. - James 5:19-20

21 SEPTEMBER.part4: Now therefore arise, go forth, and speak comfortably unto thy servants: for I swear by the LORD, if thou go not forth, there will not tarry one with thee this night: and that will be worse unto thee than all the evil that befell thee from thy youth until now.
21 SEPTEMBER.part5:
No parent desires to outlive their children. Certainly, David was filled with grief and sorrow. However, there is a time when sorrow goes too far, and we over-indulge our grief. In these circumstances, we need a wake-up call. Joab gave such a call and warning to David to provoke him to speak in a friendly manner to the people who had risked their lives for him. If not, the consequences would be far worse than anything he had experienced before.

Remember, this is David who had faced great dangers in his life: As a shepherd boy, he had fought off predators; he had slain a giant. David had to flee for his life from a vengeful king; and suffered the betrayal of his own son. Yet if David did not heed Joab's warning and persisted in his dismal state, his people would abandon him. He would be deserted and defenseless, and his kingdom would be vulnerable to defeat by their enemies.

These words went straight to David's heart. Likewise, the Lord Jesus' words to the woman at the well [John 4:18] was like a dagger to her heart. Although proven to be effective in these narratives, we have to carefully determine if they are necessary. And when stern rebuke is necessary, remember to "[speak] the truth in love" [Ephesians 4:15]. We are directed to pray for wisdom and guidance in our speech so that it is not used to cut down but to edify the body of believers.
21 SEPTEMBER.part7: There is "a time to weep" [Ecclesiastes 3:4a], but we should not be oblivious to the circumstances around us.

22 SEPTEMBER.part4: And Absalom, whom we anointed over us, is dead in battle. Now therefore why speak ye not a word of bringing the king back?
22 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Areversal of public opinion now takes place among the people, and they call on their leaders to reinstate the king. They reflect upon all the good things David had done for the country and also saw the futility of following a dead king. Their obligation is no longer to Absalom and his rebellion but to David.

Notice also David's path to restoration as the king begins with his humble compliance to Joab's instructions. Had David not spoken kindly to his servants and sat as the king in the place of authority (sitting at the gate), the people would have departed in discouragement and left David defenseless and susceptible to defeat. Humility precedes restoration. The Lord Jesus humbled Himself by taking on flesh and dwelling among man and is now exalted at the right hand of God. Joseph, the beloved child of Jacob, was humbled through many painful experiences before being elevated to be the exalted administrator over all Egypt.

In like manner, unbelievers have broken their fellowship with God. Only when we humble ourselves seeking God for repentance and acknowledge that we cannot save ourselves, will our fellowship be restored. And as sinners saved by grace, we are promoted to a higher position, to not only judge the world but to also judge the angels [1 Corinthians 6:2-3].

As Christians in the process of sanctification, may we put on "humbleness of mind" [Colossians 3:12]. No matter our age, position or length of service in the church, may we put on humility and lend our ears to wisdom.
22 SEPTEMBER.part7: He hath put down the mighty from their seats, and exalted them of low degree. - Luke 1:52

23 SEPTEMBER.part4: And king David sent to Zadok and to Abiathar the priests, saying, Speak unto the elders of Judah, saying, Why are ye the last to bring the king back to his house? seeing the speech of all Israel is come to the king, even to his house.
23 SEPTEMBER.part5:
During Absalom's usurpation, Zadok and Abiathar worked undercover in Jerusalem, gathering intelligence for David [2 Samuel 15:27- 28]. David now instructs Zadok and Abiathar to question the elders of Judah: "Why are ye the last to bring the king back to his house?" The operative word here is "last", as it subtly informs Judah that everyone else is already back with David. The repetition of the pronoun "ye" underscores David's relationship with these leaders: "Ye are my brethren, ye are my bones and my flesh: wherefore then are ye the last to bring back the king?" [v. 12]

Though it can be read as a veiled threat, it seems more likely David's message was intended to build alliances rather than intimidate. David seeks to re- establish his rule in Jerusalem without resorting to armed force. So he opts for reconciliation with his rivals including Absalom's commander, Amasa, who is to replace Joab. By swearing an oath before God that Amasa will replace Joab as David's army commander, David establishes a truce with Amasa, and Amasa brings the people of Judah who had sided with Absalom, back to David.

Although there were political reasons for Amasa's appointment, David sought reconciliation instead of violence to regain the throne. As Paul instructed in Romans 12:18b, we are to "live peaceably with all men". Reconciliation does not bear grudges, but rather forgives the past. Remember we were once sinners estranged from God, yet God offered peace to all who believe and repent. And because of God's grace and mercy, not one sin is held against us. Is there someone that you need to reconcile with today?
23 SEPTEMBER.part7: Blessed are the peacemakers: for they shall be called the children of God. - Matthew 5:9

24 SEPTEMBER.part4: And he bowed the heart of all the men of Judah, even as the heart of one man; so that they sent this word unto the king, Return thou, and all thy servants.
24 SEPTEMBER.part5:
What a turn of events! David had fled Jerusalem a desperate fugitive, rejected by the nation and hunted by his son. Now he is escorted back by thousands of supporters [v. 15]. David's appeal was heard and thus Amasa persuaded the people of Judah to a wholehearted support of God's anointed, sending word to invite him back to the city. David didn't sway just a few, but all the men of Judah unanimously. Their desire for David's return could not be coerced, their hearts had to be swayed.

Many parallels can be made between David's restoration to the throne of Israel and God's restoration to the throne of our hearts. Like David, God will not force His reign on us. We must welcome Him into our hearts. Just as the people of Judah were swayed by David's appeal of reconciliation and forgiveness, we are swayed by the grace and the mercy of God. And just as David's relationship with the people was restored, so is God's fellowship with us restored upon repentance.

David's reign and restoration required the continual support and submission of the people. Likewise, for God to continue to reign in our hearts, we must submit our lives to Him without reserve. To make His Son Jesus the Lord of our hearts, we must obey His Word, and exercise diligence to separate and remove the doubt and sins that remain in our lives [2 Peter 1:10]. Only then can we say that God truly reigns as the King of our hearts.
24 SEPTEMBER.part7: Dear God, may You reign over me, lead me, guide me, so that I may live a life that is pleasing to You.

25 SEPTEMBER.part4: And Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite, which was of Bahurim, hasted and came down with the men of Judah to meet king David.
25 SEPTEMBER.part5:
We read about the former acts of Shimei in 2 Samuel 16:5-14. At the lowest point of David's life, Shimei had rubbed salt into his wounds. He hurled curses and threw stones at David and his men as they came to Bahurim, blaming the demise of Saul and his house on David, and exulting that his dismal situation was his deserved punishment. The distraught and weary David then, had received Shimei's accusation with humility. He did not retaliate but turned to the LORD.

In today's verses, the situation has changed dramatically. David was returning to Jerusalem in jubilation after Absalom's rebellion was quelled. And Shimei was among the first to welcome him - he together with a thousand men of Benjamin, even crossed the Jordan before David so that they could be rightly seen as receiving him home.

What caused this change of attitude in Shimei? We can only see one reason - fear. His earlier speculation was wrong. Absalom's revolt did not end David's reign. King David's return would mean Shimei was in big trouble. Thus fearing for his life, Shimei was trying to reverse his past folly. There is no evidence of genuine repentance in Shimei. But it is evident he is trying to save his own skin.

This reversal of allegiance will prove to be a matter of convenience and his respite temporary. Years later in David's final instructions to Solomon, it becomes clear that David had seen through Shimei's hypocrisy. David said to his son, "Now therefore hold him (Shimei) not guiltless: for thou art a wise man, and knowest what thou oughtest to do unto him; but his hoar head bring thou down to the grave with blood" [1 Kings 2:9].
25 SEPTEMBER.part7: Be careful with your words. "A fool uttereth all his mind: but a wise man keepeth it in till afterwards." - Proverbs 29:11

26 SEPTEMBER.part4: And said unto the king, Let not my lord impute iniquity unto me, neither do thou remember that which thy servant did perversely the day that my lord the king went out of Jerusalem, that the king should take it to his heart. For thy servant doth know that I have sinned: therefore, behold, I am come the first this day of all the house of Joseph to go down to meet my lord the king.
26 SEPTEMBER.part5:
There was no way Shimei could take back what he had said to David. The only thing he could do was to confess that he had indeed done perversely against his lord and plead for David to forgive and forget this offence against him. He had sinned against God's anointed king, and to claim his sincerity in repentance, he was quick to point out he was the first to meet the king that day.

"Seest thou a man that is hasty in his words? there is more hope of a fool than of him" [Proverbs 29:20]. Shimei is a good example of one who does not watch his tongue. To be fair, it was natural for Shimei to think negatively of David's reign, given that he was also from the house of Benjamin. In the annals of history, this is something new kings have always to deal with - the sentiment and allegiance of those who served and prospered under the previous, and especially if the new king was from a different house.

Had Shimei kept his thoughts to himself then, he would not be caught in the situation we read today. He had humiliated and mocked the king publicly - the allegations were so serious and his attitude so disrespectful that the king's men had wanted to kill him there and then [2 Samuel 16:9]. Now that the king is back, it is almost impossible not to deal with this public transgression that had been committed. King David could do one of two things - punish Shimei to assert his authority, or spare Shimei to show his graciousness; and to the latter Shimei was appealing.
26 SEPTEMBER.part7: He that hath knowledge spareth his words: and a man of understanding is of an excellent spirit. Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted wise: and he that shutteth his lips is esteemed a man of understanding. - Proverbs 17:27-28

27 SEPTEMBER.part4: And David said, What have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah, that ye should this day be adversaries unto me? shall there any man be put to death this day in Israel? for do not I know that I am this day king over Israel?
27 SEPTEMBER.part5: Abishai had wanted to kill Shimei since their first encounter [2 Samuel 16:9]. David had stopped him that time for two reasons: first, he saw Shimei's cursing as chastisement from God [2 Samuel 16:10- 11]; and second, in not retaliating, David had hoped for God's mercy. In his own words, "It may be that the LORD will look on mine affliction, and that the LORD will requite me good for his cursing this day" [2 Samuel 16:12]. Now that everything has been set right for David, Abishai again asked for Shimei's head, "because he cursed the LORD's anointed" [v. 21]. But again, David had two thoughts in sparing Shimei's life now: first, he said, "What have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah, that ye should this day be adversaries unto me?" Shimei had brought along one thousand men from Benjamin in homage [2 Samuel 19:17]. If David were to kill Shimei, it might strain the relationship between him and the house of Benjamin. Then, more importantly, David also said, "Shall there any man be put to death this day in Israel? for do not I know that I am this day king over Israel?" Being able to return to Jerusalem, David was grateful. God had chastised him and then shown mercy. He should therefore be gracious and grant forgiveness to another who now came before him expressing repentance. "Blessed are the merciful: for they shall obtain mercy" [Matthew 5:7]. As difficult as it is, we must control our natural impulse and instead show mercy. A spirit of forgiveness must fill and control our hearts.
27 SEPTEMBER.part7: And be ye kind one to another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another, even as God for Christ's sake hath forgiven you. - Ephesians 4:32

28 SEPTEMBER.part4: And it came to pass, when he was come to Jerusalem to meet the king, that the king said unto him, Wherefore wentest not thou with me, Mephibosheth?
28 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Our attention now shifts to Mephibosheth. In 2 Samuel 16:1-4, we read that his servant Ziba had come to David with a gift of supplies and stinging slander against his master. Ziba said then, "Behold, he abideth at Jerusalem: for he said, To day shall the house of Israel restore me the kingdom of my father" [2 Samuel 16:3b]. By Ziba's account, Mephibosheth was rejoicing over David's departure and chose to stay in Jerusalem waiting to be restored to the throne. David had reacted hastily then and transferred everything in Saul's house to Ziba's ownership [2 Samuel 16:4].

Now, Mephibosheth came with a different story. But first we note his appearance. He "had neither dressed his feet, nor trimmed his beard, nor washed his clothes, from the day the king departed until the day he came again in peace". Mephibosheth was apparently mourning for David when he was away, which begs the question David asked, "Wherefore wentest not thou with me, Mephibosheth?"

David had made an impulsive and hasty decision when he gave all of Saul's property to Ziba. Treacherous Ziba had caught David in a state of weariness and confusion from all his troubles. David should have composed himself, prayed for guidance and listened to both sides of the story.

Our vision is often obscured by our circumstances. We cannot see beyond our predicament. In times like these, take a step back, pray and ask for God's wisdom to see things in the right light. Be not hasty in our decisions especially in times of crises; commit everything to the LORD and wait upon Him.
28 SEPTEMBER.part7: If any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given him. - James 1:5

29 SEPTEMBER.part4: And he hath slandered thy servant unto my lord the king; but my lord the king is as an angel of God: do therefore what is good in thine eyes.
29 SEPTEMBER.part5:
Mephibosheth presented his side of the story. Ziba had lied to him, saying he would prepare a donkey so lame Mephibosheth could follow David in leaving Jerusalem. The donkey did not come, and he had to stay behind [v. 26]. Ziba furthermore slandered him before David saying Mephibosheth had stayed back with the intention of hoping to be the next king.

Hearing this account, which is entirely different from Ziba's, we can imagine David's confusion. He probably regretted his hasty decision to punish Mephibosheth by giving all to Ziba. But Mephibosheth had not come seeking redress for his grievances. Neither did he blame David for believing Ziba and making his uninformed (and unwise) judgement. Instead, Mephibosheth called David "an angel of God" who is entitled to "do therefore what is good in thine eyes".

His rationale was this: "For all of my father's house were but dead men before my lord the king: yet didst thou set thy servant among them that did eat at thine own table. What right therefore have I yet to cry any more unto the king?" [v. 28]. Mephibosheth realised that if not for the hesed love and mercy of David before, he would not have survived till this day. How could he then demand anything from David?

This is the condition of mankind as well. If not for God's covenantal love, we would be nothing but condemned sinners. There are no grounds for us to demand "fairness", for if fairness was God's yardstick, then we should all perish. Yet God loves us and gives us His best even though we do not deserve anything at all.
29 SEPTEMBER.part7: But by the grace of God I am what I am: and His grace which was bestowed upon me was not in vain; but I laboured more abundantly than they all: yet not I, but the grace of God which was with me. - 1 Corinthians 15:10

30 SEPTEMBER.part4: And the king said unto him, Why speakest thou any more of thy matters? I have said, Thou and Ziba divide the land.
30 SEPTEMBER.part5:
David had a decision to make. On the one hand, there was Ziba, who had pledged his allegiance and supplied provisions to David when he fled Jerusalem [2 Samuel 16:1-4]. On the other, there was Mephibosheth, whom David had promised Jonathan to take care of [1 Samuel 20:14- 15]. One of them had told a lie, and David could have asked for a trial to find out the truth. But David did not do so, instead he decided to let Ziba and Mephibosheth divide Saul's land.

Most commentators would say it was Ziba who lied; it is quite difficult to see how Absalom's revolt would lead to lame Mephibosheth being restored. But correct or not, David's decision to divide the land seemed to have brought the case to a close. We are not told of Ziba's response to having half of his property returned to his former master, but we read here that Mephibosheth was grateful. He said to David, "Yea, let him take all, forasmuch as my lord the king is come again in peace unto his own house" [v. 30]. He would let Ziba have everything as long as David returned. That was his only concern.

Perhaps some of us are not satisfied with how this matter was resolved. Surely the liar must be punished, and the rightful owner restored all he had lost. Yet who can hold on to any riches on earth for eternity? The things in this world are nothing compared to treasures in heaven. It is in this spirit that we can echo Mephibosheth by saying, "Yea, let the world take all, forasmuch as we can eat continually at the King's table."
30 SEPTEMBER.part7: I'd rather have Jesus than silver or gold; I'd rather be His than have riches untold; I'd rather have Jesus than houses or lands; I'd rather be led by His nail-pierced hand Than to be the king of a vast domain, or be held in sin's dread sway; I'd rather have Jesus than anything this world affords today. - Oscar C. A. Bernadotte

1 OCTOBER.part4: Now Barzillai was a very aged man, even fourscore years old: and he had provided the king of sustenance while he lay at Mahanaim; for he was a very great man.
1 OCTOBER.part5:
To escape Absalom, David and his army fled eastwards across the Jordan and sought refuge at the fortified city of Mahanaim in the region of Gilead. During the months there, Barzillai, a wealthy and aged man together with Shobi and Machir sustained David, his family and his men with supplies and shelter [2 Samuel 17:27]. By succouring David, Barzillai was courageous, risking his life and those of his household.

Barzillai saw in David the God-appointed King of Israel. Godly and wise, he revered God and all that is of Him. Despite his advanced years, Barzillai determined to support and accord affection and loyalty to his king [Romans 13:7]. He counted it his privilege and duty to sustain his king in fulfilling the purpose and will of his sovereign God. He understood that all his wealth was from God [Deuteronomy 8:18] who had sovereignly purposed and enabled him for such a time as this. God regarded Barzillai a "very great man" [v. 32b] not for his wealth but for his heart. He was not avaricious nor stingy with his possessions but freely and generously provided for the king, the servant of God.

We have received a great salvation, abundant benefits and blessings from the Lord [Psalm 103] but they are for the Master's use. We are only stewards and unprofitable servants. Old Barzillai was wise, courageous, generous and loyal to his king. May our hearts too be filled with love and loyalty to Christ our Saviour King so that we will render our all to Him.
1 OCTOBER.part7: All to Thee, my blessed Saviour, I surrender all. - Judson W. Van De Venter

2 OCTOBER.part4: And the king said unto Barzillai, Come thou over with me, and I will feed thee with me in Jerusalem.
2 OCTOBER.part5:
This is one of the most touching scenes in Old Testament history. It shows the return of an exiled king to his city and throne after a tumultuous season and the beautiful character of a venerable old man who had befriended him in his time of need. Now, conscious that his own earthly journey is nearly done, Barzillai bids his king an affectionate farewell. Beyond the needful sustenance provided by the aged saint to the king and his men, an endearing bond of love and friendship between them was born and sealed by the God of love, mercy and grace. How true that when brethren in the household of faith minister and co-labour with one another in unity, bonds of friendship and love are nurtured and strengthened.

Though a king, David did not feel entitled to the kindness of his commoner-subject. He was grateful and ready to return Barzillai's kindness as he had previously done in reciprocating Jonathan's [1 Samuel 20:11-16; 2 Samuel 9:1-13]. We too can emulate David's example to manifest this wonderful fruit of the Spirit [Colossians 3:12]. David invited Barzillai to Jerusalem to stay with him - "... and I will feed thee ..." to repay Barzillai's kindness and continue enjoying his company and counsel.

Our Lord Jesus having saved us, undeserving sinners, by His death on the cross, has condescended to call us His "friend". He desires us to be in constant communion with Him. Let us in humble gratitude seek our Saviour King daily in prayer and devotion, and hear His still small voice speaking to us.
2 OCTOBER.part7: "Ye are my friends, if ye do whatsoever I command you" [John 15:14]; "Draw nigh to God, and He will draw nigh to you" [James 4:8a].

3 OCTOBER.part4: Let thy servant, I pray thee, turn back again, that I may die in mine own city, and be buried by the grave of my father and of my mother. But behold thy servant Chimham; let him go over with my lord the king; and do to him what shall seem good unto thee.
3 OCTOBER.part5:
When Barzillai extended his generosity and hospitality to his sovereign, he did not expect anything in return [v. 36b]. To Barzillai, it was his privilege and honour to serve the God-anointed king. The king's recompense for his loyalty was great indeed. Believers called to heaven one day will be amazed at the great disproportion between the recompense and their service rendered to the Lord Jesus Christ on earth [Matthew 25:37-40; 1 Corinthians 3:14].

Barzillai humbly declined the king's invitation to live in his palace giving the reason "I am this day fourscore years old" [v. 35a]. His impaired faculties of taste and hearing would not appreciate the pleasures of the court. His frail body would lack the vigour to be engaged in its affairs and activities. The pleasures and attractions of the world held no appeal to him anymore. These are not the complaints and moanings of a demented old man but wise words of a venerable one who was fully contented with his state. "Godliness with contentment is great gain" [1 Timothy 6:6]. Conscious that the end of his earthly sojourn was drawing nigh, he wished to die in his city and be buried beside his parents. He looked forward to going "home". So Barzillai offered in his place his son Chimham to follow and serve the king.

As we sojourn for a brief season in this world, may the Lord free us from its attractions and entanglements to look forward to the heavenly home already prepared for us. "In my Father's house are many mansions: if it were not so, I would have told you. I go to prepare a place for you" [John 14:2].
3 OCTOBER.part7: Turn your eyes upon Jesus, look full in His wonderful face; And the things of earth will grow strangely dim, In the light of His glory and grace. - Helen H. Lemmel

4 OCTOBER.part4: And the king answered, Chimham shall go over with me, and I will do to him that which shall seem good unto thee: and whatsoever thou shalt require of me, that will I do for thee.
4 OCTOBER.part5:
As Barzillai declined the king's invitation to go to Jerusalem, he requested permission for his son Chimham to go in his place for the king's service. Barzillai was unselfish in his willingness to give his son whatever privileges he did not claim for himself. His higher motive was to maintain the continuity of his family's service to the king and ensure that the love and loyalty for the Lord's anointed would not die with him but continue with his offspring.

It behoves every Christian parent to bring up their children in the nurture of God's Word and His love [Deuteronomy 6:5-7; Proverbs 22:6] so that in time to come, they too will serve the Lord in extending His kingdom on earth for His glory.

The king acceded to Barzillai's request and promised, "I will do to him that which shall seem good unto thee ... and whatsoever thou shalt require of me, that will I do for thee."

David later gave Chimham a piece of land near Bethlehem [Jeremiah 41:17] and on his death-bed charged his heir Solomon to show kindness to the sons of Barzillai [1 Kings 2:7]. David as an earthly king showed much love, kindness and generosity. What more our Heavenly King who purchased us with His precious blood, adopted us into His family and daily showers us with His bountiful blessings. He hears our prayers and grants our requests according to His perfect and holy will. Amazing grace! Marvellous love!
4 OCTOBER.part7: Give of thy sons to bear the message glorious, Give of thy wealth to speed them on their way, Pour out thy soul for them in prayer victorious, And all that thou spendest Jesus shall repay. - Mary A. Thompson

5 OCTOBER.part4: And the words of the men of Judah were fiercer than the words of the men of Israel.
5 OCTOBER.part5:
David arrived at Gilgal, and he was welcomed by all of Judah, and half of Israel were with him there. It is most likely that those were from the tribe of Benjamin, who were already with David before the war with Absalom. David's hold on the throne, however, was not secured as yet.

He had barely crossed the Jordan before rivalry arose between the men of Judah and the men of Israel. The latter accused the men of Judah of stealing the king from them [v. 41]. The men of Judah, on the other hand, claimed that they were just close relatives [v. 42]. The contention was sharp between them. The men of Israel argued that they had "ten parts" in the king, and they had "also more right in David" than the men of Judah [v. 43].

However, "the words of the men of Judah were fiercer". The word "fierce" is translated as "grievous" [1 Kings 12:4] or "cruel" [Genesis 49:7]. The words of the men of Judah became harsher as they hardened their stand. And they prevailed.

This fraternal contention was never resolved, driving a wedge between Judah and the rest, which eventually led to disunity, schism and war.

Quarrels result from unfulfilled desires [James 4:1]. And the war of words often results from accusatory speech provoking an equally incensed response. Solomon reminds us that "a soft answer turneth away wrath: but grievous words stir up anger" [Proverbs 15:1]. Both sides could have adopted a different approach which would have resulted in a different outcome. If only they had looked at the matter from the other's perspective and considered their feelings - and if only we would do the same.
5 OCTOBER.part7: Step into the other person's shoes, and you will not step on his toes.

6 OCTOBER.part4: And there happened to be there a man of Belial, whose name was Sheba, the son of Bichri, a Benjamite: and he blew a trumpet, and said, We have no part in David, neither have we inheritance in the son of Jesse: every man to his tents, O Israel.
6 OCTOBER.part5:
The first two verses stated that even though Sheba a man of Belial (wicked), a Benjamite, persuaded the northern Israelite tribes to abandon David, Judah remained loyal to King David. Sheba chose this critical time to stage a revolt for several reasons. First, he had a personal agenda. As a loyalist to Saul who was also from the same tribe, he saw his chance to oppose David. Second, he was an opportunist, taking advantage of David's weakened position following the unrest of the people due to Absalom's failed rebellion. Third, he had no regard for God, who raised David's kingship.

Sheba's folly is defiance against God. He rejected God's choice of David as king. He dismissed David's right to rule over him or the ten tribes of Israel ("we have no part in David"). He despised David's humble beginning as the son of Jesse ("neither have we inheritance in the son of Jesse"). He caused the people to desert David ("every man to his tents, O Israel"). As a result, Sheba succeeded in drawing away the ten northern tribes, and David faced another civil war.

What does the Bible say about those who foolishly choose to oppose God? "The kings of the earth set themselves, and the rulers take counsel together, against the LORD, and against his anointed, saying, Let us break their bands asunder, and cast away their cords from us. He that sitteth in the heavens shall laugh" [Psalm 2:2-4a]. "The Lord shall laugh at him: for he seeth that his day is coming" [Psalm 37:13]. May the Lord help us be wise and not be moved by the foolishness of those who rebel against Him.
6 OCTOBER.part7: Folly is joy to him that is destitute of wisdom: but a man of understanding walketh uprightly. - Proverbs 15:21

7 OCTOBER.part4: And David came to his house at Jerusalem; and the king took the ten women his concubines, whom he had left to keep the house, and put them in ward, and fed them, but went not in unto them. So they were shut up unto the day of their death, living in widowhood.
7 OCTOBER.part5:
This action on David's part to house and care for his concubines but separate himself from them might seem strange. There are reasons. First, David took pre-emptive measure. He did not want a repeat of his concubines being openly abused by Sheba which was what Absalom did [2 Samuel 16:20-22]. Second, David knew the shameful deed committed by Absalom was part of the consequences of his sins of adultery and murder even though through repentance he had been forgiven. "Now therefore the sword shall never depart from thine house; because thou hast despised me, and hast taken the wife of Uriah the Hittite to be thy wife" [2 Samuel 12:10]. Third, as a result, David knew the civil war sparked by Sheba was no accident but in keeping with God's Word to him. Fourth, by providing for the women, keeping them safe and leaving them alone, proved David's sincerity he would have nothing to do with more wives. Fifth, David cast himself upon the Lord's mercies for His help and deliverance.

None of us can say we are not as bad as David in his testimony of shame.
